> >=
 > > 
> > > > Hi,
> > > > 
> > > >     Some months have been since my last =
mail, I have been 
> > > researching
> > > > two stuffs:
> > > > 
> > > > 1=
)  Use of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) with NEAT  (see
> > > > http://www.=
idsia.ch/~juergen/lstm/ to know more about LSTM).
> > > > 2)  Development o=
f Work methods to use NEAT-LSTM and some 
> > > classifiers
> > > > like Ca=
scade-Adaboost to solve real Automation Industry 
> problems 
> > > in a
> =
> > > feasible way.
> > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > 1) NEAT-LSTM:
> > > > Abstrac=
t:
> > > >        The LSTM are a cell of neurons that are able to store a 
=
> > > value
> > > > during long periods. That is a problem in all Recurrent=
 
> Networks,
> > > > values are difficult to store more than 10-50 iterati=
ons in the
> > > > network (see LSTM Link for references). 
> > > > 
> > > =
> 	I put LSTM inside a NEAT. The evolution make NEAT to use 
> > > LSTM cel=
ls
> > > > in a productive way storing key values, recovering that values 
=
> when
> > > > they are useful a forgetting them  if it is useful (The 3 LS=
TM 
> cell
> > > > functions).
> > > > 
> > > > 	My analysis of some of the=
 solved problems suggest that LSTM 
> > > helps to
> > > > NEAT in some pro=
blems to reduce greatly the searching space 
> > > helping to
> > > > memor=
ize (some times to accumulate) some important key events 
> that 
> > > are=

> > > > used after to get out the right outputs.
> > > > 
> > > > 	An intu=
itional example about reduction of searching space is 
> > > serial
> > > >=
 XOR, if you solve serial XOR with NEAT you can see that the 
> > > solutio=
n
> > > > net use recurrent connection to store the first value and 
> late=
r it
> > > > compares with second value in the serial sequence. In my 
> co=
mputer 
> > > (P4
> > > > 2,4Ghz) it last around  2 minutes to find a solut=
ion with NEAT 
> > > alone.
> > > > However, when I use one LSTM cell in th=
e NEAT-LSTM it last 
> ONLY 5
> > > > SECONDS!!!!!.
> > > > 
> > > > 2)  Im=
proving Work Methods in Real Automation Problems:
> > > > 
> > > >       Mo=
tivation: Evolution systems have been achieving great 
> > > results
> > > =
> in last years. In my daily work in automation projects 
> business, I
> >=
 > > have to face another problem: cost. That is the reason that 
> most of=

> > > > the times the industry try to avoid complex systems. Complex 
> > =
> systems
> > > > are difficult to develop, difficult to modify and difficu=
lt to
> > > > maintenance. Most of the times, it is the last choosen 
> res=
ource. 
> > > > 
> > > > 	Other problems to use evolution systems are the 
=
> > > uncertainty.  Always,
> > > > there is some likelihood that a problem=
 will converge to a 
> > > solution in
> > > > a reasonable time. Some time=
 we can evaluate it, sizing the 
> > > searching
> > > > space. Other times=
 it very difficult to size such space. 
> > > Uncertainty
> > > > is a vari=
able related to, what is known in business as, risk. 
> > > > 
> > > > 	Som=
e recent experiment as in 
> > > > http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/downloads/papers=
/whiteson.gecco03.pdf 
> > > suggest
> > > > that a way to reduce searching=
 space is to "draw" the guide
> > > > where the
> > > > solution will be se=
arched. Some of my research has gone in that
> > > > direction. In most of =
the systems we have deal with, we have 
> some
> > > > previous knowledge a=
bout them. My work is focusing in how 
> organize
> > > > such previous kno=
wledge in: decision trees, tasks, abstraction 
> > > levels
> > > > and int=
erdependences among them to reduce as much as possible 
> the
> > > > searc=
hing space. So the final goal is to find feasibility work 
> > > methods
> =
> > > and tools to use evolution systems in real automation Industry
> > > =
> problems.
> > > > 
> > > > Regards.
> > > > 
> > > > Germ=E1n.
